text: A human conversation is often all that's needed in my experience. But IMHO a logo is the least valuable form of advocacy you can get. My company often bakes it into renewal contracts and we'll ask along with approval requests for case studies, testimonial videos, etc since we're probably using their logo in those anyway.

text:
Happy Friday Eve, everyone! I’m currently working on evolving the demand gen efforts at my company - though, events, partnerships and product are all part of other teams. We own inbound, social, PR, syndicated, content (blog/whitepapers/ebooks, etc), and the like. For demand gen, in terms of building out a team, I’m stumped as to what kind of roles we may need to add down the line - I’m noodling on some sort of analytics/data focus and possibly email. We have 2 content producers and a social/community management person. Anyone have any tips for what kind of specific roles should be on a demand gen team with this makeup? All the articles I’ve looked at are pretty much conflicting with the way our team is made up.

Thank you!!

elements.text:
Happy Friday Eve, everyone! I’m currently working on evolving the demand gen efforts at my company - though, events, partnerships and product are all part of other teams. We own inbound, social, PR, syndicated, content (blog/whitepapers/ebooks, etc), and the like. For demand gen, in terms of building out a team, I’m stumped as to what kind of roles we may need to add down the line - I’m noodling on some sort of analytics/data focus and possibly email. We have 2 content producers and a social/community management person. Anyone have any tips for what kind of specific roles should be on a demand gen team with this makeup? All the articles I’ve looked at are pretty much conflicting with the way our team is made up.

Thank you!!

text: The demand gen portion or our marketing team includes a marketing automation person (responsible for campaign setup, system assets, lead scoring, email, etc.) and a couple of segment marketing managers who each handle the kinds of programs you mentioned for different segments of our audience.

elements.text: The demand gen portion or our marketing team includes a marketing automation person (responsible for campaign setup, system assets, lead scoring, email, etc.) and a couple of segment marketing managers who each handle the kinds of programs you mentioned for different segments of our audience.

text: Although my demand gen team is just me right now, in my last role our demand gen team had 2 content producers (one with SEO focus, one a generalist who handled social media and email marketing), an automation/ads person, and an events specialist. Definitely worth having someone working on the inbound ops side, working on analytics and optimization, even if that role covers other responsibilities too. And personally I'd hire someone who's really good at paid social and Google Ads if that's an important channel for you. Having a great design/dev marketing resource really helps too though they probably sit outside this team

elements.text: Although my demand gen team is just me right now, in my last role our demand gen team had 2 content producers (one with SEO focus, one a generalist who handled social media and email marketing), an automation/ads person, and an events specialist. Definitely worth having someone working on the inbound ops side, working on analytics and optimization, even if that role covers other responsibilities too. And personally I'd hire someone who's really good at paid social and Google Ads if that's an important channel for you. Having a great design/dev marketing resource really helps too though they probably sit outside this team

text:
Hi everyone,

I'm currently researching a new guide: "How to Create Product-Led SaaS Content Strategy." If you have some resources that helped you to create yours or you'll like to share your real life experience (*I'll give you full attribution+backlink*), kindly shoot me a DM.

*Besides, what do you think of these subject lines:*
How to Create a Winning SaaS Content Strategy in the PLG Era
How to Create a Great SaaS Content Strategy in the PLG Era
3 Steps to Create a Great SaaS Content Strategy for the PLG Era
3 Steps to Create a Winning Product-Led Growth Content Strategy
3 Steps to Create a Winning Product-Led Growth Content Strategy
How to Create a SaaS Content Strategy Unique to PLG
The Steps I’ll Take to Create a PLG Content Strategy
Content Strategy in the PLG Era: 3 Steps to Get it Right
How to Develop a Content Strategy for a PLG Brand
3 Steps to Develop Content Strategy for a PLG SaaS
3 Steps I’ll Use to Recreate Your PLG Content Strategy

Which once cuts your fancy?

text:
Does your org have an existing product marketing function? If not, I might consider bulking up there to get those BOFU leads.

I'm also a big fan of having a "campaign manager" who can lead efforts around big ideas. Once you have a marketing team that is all channel owners, trying to coordinate across channels gets bumpy :sweat_smile: But it's likely your existing PMs are equipped to do that work.

Co-marketing is definitely a good one.

Overall, be wary of adding too many channels at once! They're not all equal. Identify your most impactful channel than invest heavily there.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

But it's likely your existing PMs are equipped to do that work.

Co-marketing is definitely a good one.

Overall, be wary of adding too many channels at once! They're not all equal. Identify your most impactful channel than invest heavily there.

text: Hello! I am looking for a good method for creating Calls to Action on our WordPress blog. We're migrating from Hubspot where it was pretty easy to set them up, but now I think we need to get a plugin. I am looking into Boxzilla but it seems like it only does moving CTAs, and I'd also like a way to create static CTAs that can be managed from one central place - vs. having to go into each individual blog post and update. Thoughts/Recommendations? Thanks!! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hello! I am looking for a good method for creating Calls to Action on our WordPress blog. We're migrating from Hubspot where it was pretty easy to set them up, but now I think we need to get a plugin. I am looking into Boxzilla but it seems like it only does moving CTAs, and I'd also like a way to create static CTAs that can be managed from one central place - vs. having to go into each individual blog post and update. Thoughts/Recommendations? Thanks!!

text: #1 - I am also currently working on this... It's a beast! Pruning a 1.5K post-blog down to around 300 posts. I hope it doesnt tank. :{}  I'm relying on page views, submissions, CTA clicks from all time, as well as from the past year, but I have to say a lot of it has simply been manual review and going with my gut for what I think will ultimately support where our business is going and where we're headed with product/sales etc. I think there's more data I could and should be pulling in - it sounds like Andy has a really thorough process - but I don't have access to the tech or time I'd like to be able to do that. This article was really awesome, but you need certain tools to be able to follow their method: <https://trafficthinktank.com/content-audit-template> As for #2, I'm also in this boat. Part of me says that I won't use URL structures that include the /hub because if I want to change the hubs ever it means more redirects, but the other part says do it for more organized folders for search crawlers. It's been hard for me to find conclusive opinions on whether it matters or not. Pls share if you find some!! :slightly_smiling_face:

attachments.title: How to do a Content Audit in 15 Minutes [Free Template Included]
attachments.text: Running a content audit across your website can uncover many different issues and opportunities. Learn how to do an audit in just 15 minutes.
attachments.fallback: Traffic Think Tank: How to do a Content Audit in 15 Minutes [Free Template Included]

text:
Hey Ashly, here are a few things we do:

- Make the most of our partner network and influencers to promo the event for us 
- Empower our sales team to reach out to individuals to invite them via email (we write the templates for them) 
- Use HubSpot pop ups on our site 
- Use our Intercom chat bot to invite web visitors
- On LinkedIn, were using a lot more video content too

Hope this helps!

text:
Hey Brianna, like most on this list, I'm rarely asked for a CV or my degree.

On the rare occasion I have to draw it up (last time in early 2019), I use it as an excuse to get creative. My experience _seems_ so disjointed, I actually annotate it! (pic coming :grin: )

On my website, I pitch this loosely as: I studied Biology, and I still love research and figuring out how stuff works.

But overall, my clients care way more about what I've done/can do, what other people say about what I've done, and what working with me is like.

text:
Partners, sales and popups are great. We’ve gone into LI groups that are relevant to post/share, looked for partners or associations to promote with, also just tried event listings on social channels and event sites (eventbrite, meetup, etc) hoping to cast our net wider.
Also if your industry has any event round up blogs, reach out to them ask to be included/promoted. Can’t hurt :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Long story short--play up the relevant stuff in how you structure your headings, callouts, skills, etc and bury the less important (So maybe education is your last bullet or really small and not detailed. Or, at least called out any relevant writing projects you did with that degree. I included “related coursework” under my education bullets to add helpful context for why my degree/schooling is related to the role’s responsibilities.)

text:
Story I heard from the VP of Marketing at CrowdRiff. They are a social media platform for tourism departments.  So their platform let's you use UGC content in your marketing -- like if you're the team from Visit Philly you might find Instagram pictures tagged with #philadelphia and use that in your marketing.

So they were attending a huge industry conference and trying to figure out how to stand out. They ended up creating a physical book that highlighted like the top 10 things to do in the city where the conference was. How amazing is that?

Such a magical way to show off what their product does in a way that was super useful in the moment. It was obviously a huge hit. Every attendee was stopping by their booth to get one.

Examples like that are hard to rip off because they're so unique to what the business does. The VP of Marketing, Amrita Gurney, is unusually good at finding these opportunities. She's done some very cool stuff around their COVID response as well.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text:
Story I heard from the VP of Marketing at CrowdRiff. They are a social media platform for tourism departments.  So their platform let's you use UGC content in your marketing -- like if you're the team from Visit Philly you might find Instagram pictures tagged with #philadelphia and use that in your marketing.

So they were attending a huge industry conference and trying to figure out how to stand out. They ended up creating a physical book that highlighted like the top 10 things to do in the city where the conference was. How amazing is that?

Such a magical way to show off what their product does in a way that was super useful in the moment. It was obviously a huge hit. Every attendee was stopping by their booth to get one.

Examples like that are hard to rip off because they're so unique to what the business does. The VP of Marketing, Amrita Gurney, is unusually good at finding these opportunities. She's done some very cool stuff around their COVID response as well.

text: Try Growmance or Online Geniuses :slightly_smiling_face: They don't really compare in quality to this one but can still be helpful!

elements.text: Try Growmance or Online Geniuses

text: <@UJG12DM1V> we did something similar when I was on the agency side! Distributing at the event + SEO made it our top lead gen tool, and even got our little agency sponsorships from Deloitte for the next year's edition

text:
I personally love when company leaders jump into the comments to help people out or stoke the conversational fires on social media (or slack/interest groups!) I see it as a form of content marketing ( but maybe it's consultative selling, SMM, influencer marketing, just being nice?!). I don't mean posting "thought leadership" content and dropping the mic but being genuinely helpful. You can find MANY examples in this group, yourself included. :)

Other things I love that may or may not be moonshot material:
• Case studies written or recorded in story form and that don't hide the setbacks, failings, and challenges
• Podcasts

text:
You said “subject line”, so am I right to assume this is for email? A few thoughts:

• Is it worth centering the idea that PLG is new and impactful to the reader? e.g. “How the new Product-Led Growth movement will affect your SaaS content” or “What content teams need to know about Product-Led Growth”.
• In general, “era” makes me think “old”. Maybe frame it as a trend, movement, wave, etc.
• “Winning” and “great” aren’t strong enough for me. I would either leave out the adjectives or go bigger by describing the content strategy as “rock-solid”, “perfect”, “step-by-step”, etc.

elements.text: You said “subject line”, so am I right to assume this is for email? A few thoughts:

Is it worth centering the idea that PLG is new and impactful to the reader? e.g. “How the new Product-Led Growth movement will affect your SaaS content” or “What content teams need to know about Product-Led Growth”.
In general, “era” makes me think “old”. Maybe frame it as a trend, movement, wave, etc.
“Winning” and “great” aren’t strong enough for me. I would either leave out the adjectives or go bigger by describing the content strategy as “rock-solid”, “perfect”, “step-by-step”, etc.

text:
<@UJE5LQ2JC> one of my favorite sites is <Https://pudding.cool|Https://pudding.cool> — they do really niche and interesting data visualization/deep dives that are often interactive. A few examples:

<https://pudding.cool/projects/votes-for-women/|https://pudding.cool/projects/votes-for-women/> (not great on mobile though)

<https://pudding.cool/2018/11/dearabby/|https://pudding.cool/2018/11/dearabby/>

<https://pudding.cool/2017/12/hater/|https://pudding.cool/2017/12/hater/>

They also have some content on their site about how they approach this work. I’ve found it really interesting and inspirational for my team!

attachments.title: The Pudding explains ideas debated in culture with visual essays.
attachments.text: The Pudding explains ideas debated in culture with visual essays.
attachments.fallback: The Pudding: The Pudding explains ideas debated in culture with visual essays.

attachments.title: Women’s Issues Within Political Party Platforms
attachments.text: Every four years political parties document their positions in written platforms. How often do women’s issues appear in the text?
attachments.fallback: The Pudding: Women’s Issues Within Political Party Platforms

attachments.title: 30 Years of American Anxieties
attachments.text: What 20,000 letters to an advice columnist tell us about what—and who—concerns us most.
attachments.fallback: The Pudding: 30 Years of American Anxieties

attachments.title: 10 Things Everyone Hates About You
attachments.text: Exploring over 30 million feelings towards 3,000+ topics.
attachments.fallback: The Pudding: 10 Things Everyone Hates About You
